loftitools¶

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.AcceptOrReject(chi2, chi_min)[source]¶

Perform rejection sampling accept/reject decision

Parameters

  • chi2 (1xN array) – array of chi2 values

  • chi_min (flt) – min chi2 value

Returns

accepted: Array of indicies of accepted

lnprob: log probability of accepted orbits

lnrand: log of the random “dice roll” for acceptance

Return type

3-tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2020

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.ComputeChi2(array, model)[source]¶

Cumpute the Chi2 for an array of model predictions and measurements

Parameters

  • array (2 x N array) – array of observations, row [0] = value, row [1] = errors

  • model (1 x N array) – array of model predicitons

Returns

Chi^2 value

Return type

flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2020

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.MonteCarloIt(thing, N=10000)[source]¶

Generate a random sample of size = N from a Gaussian centered at thing[0] with std thing[1]

Parameters

  • thing (tuple, flt) – tuple of (value,uncertainty). Can be either astropy units object or float

  • N (int) – number of samples

Returns

N random samples from a Gaussian.

Return type

array

Written by Logan Pearce, 2020

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.add_in_quad(thing)[source]¶

Add elements of an array of things in quadrature

Parameters

thing (arr, flt) – array of things to add in quadrature

Returns

single value of things added in quadrature

Return type

flt

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.calc_OFTI(parameters, date, rho, pa)[source]¶

Perform OFTI steps to determine position/velocity/acceleration predictions given orbital elements.

Parameters

  • Parameters (9 x N array) –

  • a (flt) – semi-major axis, as

  • T (flt) – period, yrs

  • to (flt) – epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates), yrs

  • e (flt) – eccentricity

  • i (flt) – inclination, rad

  • w (flt) – argument of periastron, rad

  • O (flt) – longitude of nodes, rad

  • m1 (flt) – system mass, Msun

  • dist (flt) – distance to system in pc, pc

  • date (flt) – observation date, yrs

  • rho (tuple, flt) – separation and error, mas

  • pa (tuple, flt) – position angle and error, deg

Returns

X, Y, Z: positions in plane of the sky in mas

X dot, Y dot, Z dot: three dimensional velocities in km/s

X ddot, Y ddot, Z ddot: 3d accelerations in m/s/yr

Return type

9-tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.calc_XYZ(a, T, to, e, i, w, O, date)[source]¶

Compute projected on-sky position only of a single object on a Keplerian orbit given a set of orbital elements at a single observation point. Called by calc_OFTI

Parameters

  • a (flt) – semi-major axis, as

  • T (flt) – period, yrs

  • to (flt) – epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates), yrs

  • e (flt) – eccentricity

  • i (flt) – inclination, rad

  • w (flt) – argument of periastron, rad

  • O (flt) – longitude of nodes, rad

  • m1 (flt) – system mass, Msun

  • date (flt) – observation date, yrs

Returns

X, Y, Z: 3d positions in mas

Return type

3-tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.calc_accel(a, T, to, e, i, w, O, date, dist, E)[source]¶

Compute 3-d acceleration of a single object on a Keplerian orbit given a set of orbital elements at a single observation point. Called by calc_OFTI

Parameters

  • a (flt) – semi-major axis, as

  • T (flt) – period, yrs

  • to (flt) – epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates), yrs

  • e (flt) – eccentricity

  • i (flt) – inclination, rad

  • w (flt) – argument of periastron, rad

  • O (flt) – longitude of nodes, rad

  • m1 (flt) – system mass, Msun

  • dist (flt) – distance to system in pc, pc

  • date (flt) – observation date, yrs

  • E (flt) – eccentricity anomaly, computed in calc_XYZ

Returns

X ddot, Y ddot, Z ddot: 3d accelerations in m/s/yr

Return type

3-tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.calc_min_credible_interval(x, alpha)[source]¶

Internal method to determine the minimum interval of a given width Assumes that x is sorted numpy array. From: https://github.com/aloctavodia/Doing_bayesian_data_analysis/blob/master/hpd.py

Parameters

  • x (arr, flt) – array of values for which to compute Min Cred Int

  • alpha (flt) – statistical alpha value; 1-alpha is the interval. Ex: alpha = 0.05 -> 95% min cred int.

Returns

hdi_min, hdi_max (flt): min and max values of interval encompassing (1-alpha)% of of the data

Return type

tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.calc_velocities(a, T, to, e, i, w, O, date, dist, E)[source]¶

Compute 3-d velocity of a single object on a Keplerian orbit given a set of orbital elements at a single observation point. Uses my eqns derived from Seager Exoplanets Ch2.

Parameters

  • a (flt) – semi-major axis, as

  • T (flt) – period, yrs

  • to (flt) – epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates), yrs

  • e (flt) – eccentricity

  • i (flt) – inclination, rad

  • w (flt) – argument of periastron, rad

  • O (flt) – longitude of nodes, rad

  • m1 (flt) – system mass, Msun

  • dist (flt) – distance to system in pc, pc

  • date (flt) – observation date, yrs

  • E (flt) – eccentricity anomaly, computed in calc_XYZ

Returns

X dot, Y dot, Z dot: 3d velocities in km/s

Return type

3-tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.compute_statistics(array)[source]¶

Compute summary statistics of an array

Parameters

array (arr, flt) – array to compute the mode

Returns

mean (flt): mean of array from np.mean

median (flt): median of array from np.median

mode (flt): mode of array

std (flt): standard deviation from np.std

ci68 (tuple, flt): 68% minimum credible interval

ci95 (tuple, flt): 95% minimum credible interval

Return type

array

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.danby_solve(f, M0, e, h, maxnum=50)[source]¶

Newton-Raphson solver for eccentricity anomaly based on “Danby” method.

Parameters

  • f (function) – function to solve (transcendental ecc. anomaly function)

  • M0 (float) – mean anomaly

  • e (float) – eccentricity

  • h (float) – termination criteria for solver

  • maxnum (int) – if it takes more than maxnum iterations, use the Mikkola solver instead.

Returns

converged solution for eccentric anomaly

Return type

flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.distance(parallax, parallax_error)[source]¶

Computes distance from Gaia parallaxes using the Bayesian method of Bailer-Jones 2015.

Parameters

parallax error (parallax,) – parallax in mas

Returns

distance (flt): distance to systems in pc

sigma (flt): 1-sigma uncertainty in distance

Return type

tuple, flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.draw_samples(number, m_tot, d_star, date)[source]¶

Draw a set of orbital elements from proability distribution functions.

Parameters are drawn from the probability distributions:

-a: single value for semi-major axis due to scale and rotate

-const: unif [0,1]

-e: unif [0,1)

-cos(i): unif [0,1]

-w: unif [0,360] deg

-O: single value fixed at 0 due to scale and rotate

Parameters

  • number (int) – number of orbits desired to draw elements for. Typically 10000

  • m_tot (tuple, flt) – total system mass[0] and error[1] in solar masses

  • d_star (tuple, flt) – distance to system in pc

  • date (flt) – observation date. 2015.5 for Gaia DR2

Returns

a (flt): semi-major axis, as

T (flt): period, yrs

to (flt): epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates), yrs

e (flt): eccentricity

i (flt): inclination, rad

w (flt): argument of periastron, rad

O (flt): longitude of nodes, rad

m1 (flt): system mass, Msun

dist (flt): distance to system

Return type

array

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.eccentricity_anomaly(E, e, M)[source]¶

Eccentric anomaly function

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.freedman_diaconis(array)[source]¶

Compute the optimal number of bins for a 1-d histogram using the Freedman-Diaconis rule of thumb Bin width = 2IQR/cuberoot(N)

Parameters

array (arr) – flattened array of data

Returns

bin_width (flt): width of bin in optimal binning

n (int): number of bins

Return type

tuple

  • name (str) – name of parameter

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.mas_to_km2(arcsec, dist)[source]¶

Convert from mas -> km using the distance rather than parallax. Does not compute errors on separation.

Parameters

  • arcsec (array, flt) – sep in arcsec

  • dist (array, flt) – distance in parsecs

Returns

separation in km

Return type

array

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019

Parameters

  • plx (tuple,float) – parallax, tuple of (plx,plx error)

Returns

Return type

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.mikkola_solve(M, e)[source]¶

Analytic solver for eccentricity anomaly from Mikkola 1987. Most efficient when M near 0/2pi and e >= 0.95.

Parameters

  • M (float) – mean anomaly

  • e (float) – eccentricity

Returns

eccentric anomaly

Return type

flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.orbits_for_plotting(a1, T1, to1, e1, i1, w1, O1, t)[source]¶

Compute inputs specifically for plotting functions

Parameters

  • [as] (a) – semi-major axis

  • [yrs] (to) – period

  • [yrs] – epoch of periastron passage (in same time structure as dates)

  • e – eccentricity

  • [rad] (O) – inclination

  • [rad] – argument of periastron

  • [rad] – longitude of nodes

  • t (flt) – time at which to compute the position

Returns

X, Y (flt): positions in plane of the sky [mas]

Return type

tuple

Written by Logan Pearce, 2020

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.scale_and_rotate(X, Y, rho, pa, a, const, m1, dist, d)[source]¶

Generates a new semi-major axis, period, epoch of peri passage, and long of peri for each orbit given the X,Y plane of the sky coordinates for the orbit at the date of the reference epoch. Called by calc_OFTI

Parameters

  • X,Y (1 x N array) – X and Y model predicted DEC/RA initial position in mas

  • rho (tuple, flt) – observed separation and error in mas

  • pa (tuple, flt) – observed position angle and error in deg

  • a (1 x N array) – initial semi-major axis

  • const (1 x N array) – initial orbit fraction

  • m1 – system mass

  • dist – distance to system

  • d – observation date (2015.5 for Gaia DR2)

Returns

a2 (1 x N array): scaled semi-major axis

T2 (1 x N array): scaled period

to2 (1 x N array): scaled periastron passage

O2 (1 x N array): rotated lon of ascending node

Return type

(4 x N array)

Written by Logan Pearce, 2018

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.solve(f, M0, e, h, maxnum=50)[source]¶

Newton-Raphson solver for eccentricity anomaly from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20659456/python-implementing-a-numerical-equation-solver-newton-raphson

Parameters

  • f (function) – function to solve (transcendental ecc. anomaly function)

  • M0 (float) – mean anomaly

  • e (float) – eccentricity

  • h (float) – termination criteria for solver

Returns

converged solution for eccentric anomaly

Return type

flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2017

lofti_gaiaDR2.loftitools.to_polar(RAa, RAb, Deca, Decb)[source]¶
Converts RA/Dec [deg] of two binary components into separation and position angle of B relative

to A [mas, deg]

Parameters

RAb, Deca, Decb (RAa,) – RA/Dec of each object in deg

Returns

separation in mas and position angle in degrees from North

Return type

tuple, flt

Written by Logan Pearce, 2019
